Author: brettski74
Content: There are low temperature solder pastes based on Tin-Bismuth-Silver alloys. They generally melt around 138 celsius. I have used an FR4 board to reflow Tin-Lead solder, so it can be done, but you might see small amounts of smoke coming off the board. There was no visible damage afterward, but I expect this will wear out the board much faster than lower temperatures. I don't plan to do this regularly. I mostly plan to use low temperature Sn-Bi-Ag solder with these boards, however, I used a spare board that I drove directly from my lab supply to reflow my first reflow board and I wanted that to use a higher temperature solder just to be on the safe side. I wouldn't do this for most regular boards.

Author: brettski74
Content: The biggest thing to worry about with the regulator is the pinout and the package. There are a lot of different regs out there that come in a SOT89 package that you could use, except that the industry apparently decided that we needed all the different possible permutations of arrangements of those three pins. The pinout is different from the SOT89 version of the 7805 and a lot of others, but there are a fair number of LDOs out there that use the same pinout and a lot of manufacturers seem to make a 1117 part that matches.

Author: brettski74
Content: I've been working on a larger plate for about a month. I'm working on a number of improvements including temperature sensing and safety. I've gone through 3 revisions so far and am getting closer, but my design also will require changes to the control circuitry. In general, to achieve a given performance, you need a certain amount of power per unit area. There are challenges around accurate temperature sensing and issues around the board edges where you lose heat faster. I haven't done too much work on variability in the manufacturing process. The few boards I have used seem pretty close but I wouldn't say I've done any serious investigation on manufacturing precision yet. Spatz has some pretty good results in terms of process precision from JLCPCB - where I've gotten most of my boards from so far as well. The other thing I've noticed is that when I calculate the expected resistance of a new design, the boards I get don't match that. I'm going to guess that it's my calculations or maybe that there's something going on at corners that my simple calculations are not accurately reflecting.

Author: brettski74
Content: Also, boiling drops of water on your heater plate because you can is a good way to destroy it. üôÇ

Author: brettski74
Content: One thing about larger boards are that getting a flatter heat profile across the board is somewhat easier. The edge effects don't seem to extend too far from the edges. If you look at the small plate on the current designs, there's quite a large variation in temperature across the plate at reflow temperatures. If you look at something like a 3d printer bed, the edge effects still occur, but since you're maybe looking at something 200x200mm instead of 70x50mm as well as lower temperatures, the temperature is flatter across most of the bed. A larger heater plate should give you a larger area in the middle that is close to the same temperature. But other than that, assume a roughly constant power per unit area to get a given performance.

Author: brettski74
Content: The current power designs seem to struggle meeting the thermal gradients in some reflow profiles in my testing so far. You need more power to get sufficient rate of temperature rise at the higher temperatures. The existing designs get to reflow temperatures - particular for low temperature solders, but seem to get there more slowly than manufacturer's reflow profiles suggest. If you want to match the reflow profiles closely, you need more power to do so, especially at the higher temperatures.

Author: brettski74
Content: But then you have safety considerations to think about. Higher power could put you into the realm of starting a fire.

Author: brettski74
Content: So there's a trade-off.

Author: brettski74
Content: The base material shouldn't affect resistance. It's still copper on top of the FR4. I did some measurements on the last batch - not as carefully as I could, but close enough. The variability was around +/-2.8%, which is about the same as Spatz's results. I calculated those resistance values as +/- 3.2%. So assume about +/-3% variability in JLCPCB's process. 29¬µm would be a fudge factor of about 1.2 on measured resistance versus calculated. That seems close to some of my results, too - at least for JLCPCB. I have some boards on the way from PCBWay to compare. I was wondering how much variability there might be between different fabs.

Author: derspatz
Content:
I just assume that the copper thickness is lower, because jlcpcb should get length and width more or less right, so the only thing that would explain the difference in calculated and actual resistance would be the thickness. And this is also the thing where "cheating" would be the easiest, and it would offer a cost benefit. Not implying that jlcpcb does this on purpose.

Author: brettski74
Content: @spelter You may be surprised. Standard FR4 boards from PCBWay seem to be more heat resistant than the ones from JLCPCB. I did a few preliminary tests a month or two ago. Unfortunately, life's kinda gotten in the way since then and I haven't been able to do much more since then, but in those preliminary tests, I was seeing about 80-100 celsius hotter where I noticed the same signs of heat damage such as light smoking, heavier smoking and delamination of the solder mask.

Author: brettski74
Content: 3d printer heated beds... there are some parallels but solder reflow is a different problem. 3d printer beds don't have any need to go above about 100 celsius, so you're never really pushing past the limits of the materials. I haven't seen an FR4 material with a glass transition temperature below about 130 celsius. On the other hand for solder reflow, you're virtually guaranteed to be blowing past the glass transition temperature of virtually every FR4 material out there. Fortunately this doesn't seem to be a major problem so far - at least in my limited experience. I've thought about aluminium as an option, but I really don't think it's worth it. Disintegration of the base material isn't the problem with heat damage over time. What you really need to worry about is deterioration and delamination of the solder mask and while I haven't seen it yet, I also suspect that delamination of the copper from the base could be a problem depending on how different the coefficients of thermal expansion are. Aluminium's coefficient of thermal expansion is typically almost 40% higher than that of copper. PCBs aren't usually designed for the kind of thermal cycling we're doing here, so I'm not sure whether they'll be using some custom Si/Al alloy to try to match coefficients of thermal expansion that closely. I could be wrong, but given the warping that other people have noticed, I think that's a pretty good indication that they're using a more common Aluminium alloy that expands way more than we'd want.

Author: brettski74
Content: In principal, yes. There's not that much different between these hotplates and a heated bed PCB for a 3d printer, although a typical heated bed PCB like the Prusa design is quite a lot larger, so getting to reflow temperatures does increase the power requirements a bit. The one you've linked is even larger than the standard Prusa design. 120W only gets you to about 90 celsius on that bad boy. Given the area of that board, you'll probably want something closer to 300-400W to reflow low temperature solders. For tin-lead solder, you're looking at closer to 500W. A 24V 20A supply would probably do the trick if you happen to have something that beefy. Unless you're reflowing things that large, you'll probably want something smaller to keep the power requirements more manageable - not to mention the fire risk.

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm also thinking that if you're reflowing something that large, you are probably better off investing in a decent reflow oven. Reflow hotplates are cool and all, but there are caveats and it is harder to get consistent temperatures across large areas with a hotplate. This is something that an oven can do much better.

Author: brettski74
Content: 65W for a 15x15cm hotplate would heat pretty slowly. I've been working with 10x10cm hotplates and they work ok. I think I could get one to about 180 celsius with only 65W, but it would take a while. That would be roughly the equilibrium temperature at 65W. So you wouldn't reflow SnPb. You could probably reflow SnBi, just really slowly. But that's on a 10x10cm hotplate. 15x15cm is over double the area, so I can't see you reaching reflow temperatures for even SnBi with only 65W. You're probably looking at closer to double that to reach reflow temperatures for SnBi alloys on a 15x15cm hotplate. If you want to follow something more like a typical reflow profile and complete the job in a reasonable amount of time, then you probably want to double that number again. So based on the work I've been doing,  250W is looking more realistic for something that large.

Author: brettski74
Content: Actually, the heated area of my hotplate is only 84x87mm... The whole board is 100x100mm, but there's a margin around the edge that has no heating element. Thermal resistance to ambient is roughly 2.4 K/W.

Author: brettski74
Content: Power into the board while following a reflow profile peaks at around 150W during the preheat stage, but you can probably ignore that. The final climb up to reflow temperatures for standard SnPb solder hits around 120W. Most of the rest of the cycle dances around 70-80W. The peak temperature for the whole cycle was around 220 celsius.

Author: brettski74
Content: It's also worth noting that for good results, you need to modify typical reflow profiles designed for use in ovens. Ovens tend to get heat into the solder and components more quickly/effectively, so I've found that for reliable results, you need to hold the reflow temperature longer on a hotplate. That said, the reflow time in the above is overkill. I'll trim that back when I have some time to figure out some minimum requirement for reliable results.

Content: how hot can jlcpcb hotplates get

Author: brettski74
Content: That depends on how well you want them to last. I've driven hotplates built using standard JLCPCB 2-layer boards well over 200 celsius and reflowed SAC305 which required temperatures up around 240-250 celsius to do reliably, but I don't really consider them suitable for reflowing anything other than low temperature SnBi alloys, because they start to show significant amounts of smoke at those temperatures and even below 200 celsius they start to regularly smoke. So I'd recommend a maximum temperature of around 180 celsius when using one as a hotplate, which is plenty for reflowing SnBi.

Author: elitesennabubble
Content: is SnBi fine for most applications?

Author: brettski74
Content: Short answer, yes. Long answer, look at my post in General from a few days ago.

Author: elitesennabubble
Content: With the miracle of Google and the internet, you can read for hours and hours on the pros and cons of various solder alloys. For most purposes, any of the commonly used alloys will work fine and you probably won't notice a difference. I personally prefer SnPb solder, because it's the alloy that we have the most experience with, it has good wetting characteristics, good mechanical properties and reasonably good conductivity. Also, if you get the eutectic alloy (63/37), it has a single, actual freezing point rather than a liquidus/solidus temperature range and this makes it easier to get good joints when hand soldering. I tend to avoid SAC alloys because of the higher temperature and the liquidus/solidus temperature range means that you end up with poor joints if there's much movement while it's freezing. I have some SnBi solder paste, but I rarely use it because the conductivity is lower, the joints are more brittle and if you use the cheapest finish on your boards (HASL with leaded solder) you risk forming SnBiPb intermetallics in the joint which may have liquidus temperatures below 100 celsius. That said, for most purposes you probably won't notice much difference and I'm probably overthinking it. (edited)

Author: brettski74
Content: I doubt it's reverse polarity. I'd expect to see the magic smoke come out pretty quick with the kind of power supply needed to drive that hotplate. The input capacitance is known to be woefully low and the PWM frequency also woefully low for what it's intended to do, so there will be a lot of current going into and out of that capacitor every cycle, but with the default firmware it shouldn't need to dissipate more about a quarter of a watt. I did a worst case scenario simulation and estimated about 320mW dissipation in the input cap assuming an ESR of 0.1 ohm. I also pulled out my old v3.0 board and ran a reflow cycle. The input cap did warm up enough to feel the difference, but it was much. Measuring it, it went from about 23 celsius at the start (ie. ambient room temperature) to about 30 celsius by the end. I'm imagining that "mighty hot" is a lot hotter than this, so it's not normal.

Author: brettski74
Content: A couple of theories:

Author: brettski74
Content: 1. Your capacitor has a high ESR. This basically means it's bad. That said, in simulations I couldn't get the power dissipation in that input capacitor above about 0.5W and I'm not sure that's enough to get a device that size "mighty hot"

Author: brettski74
Content: 2. Your capacitor has a short - ie. it's really bad.

Author: brettski74
Content: 3. You changed the firmware to increase the PWM frequency. Higher PWM frequency *could* be good, but even at 63kHz - which is where the AVR MCUs kinda max out, the input capacitance is still woefully low. In simulations I can get the power dissipation in a reasonably healthy, jelly-bean capacitor to around 8W. That would probably get it nicely hot. That said, I figure you probably would have said something if you'd modified the firmware.

Author: brettski74
Content: I see that the person who posted the original question on github mentioned a frequency of 31.5 kHz, which aligns well with theory #3 of mine.

Author: brettski74
Content: Interesting... I notice that the original v2.4 code from Chris does actually update the timer/counter control registers to increase the PWM frequency, but the v3.0 code most commonly used - mine - has that commented out. This is something I inherited from the vonryan123 fork which I forked. So I'm guessing most of us running v3.0 builds are using the default 490Hz PWM frequency, whereas if you're running v2.4, then you're probably using Chris's code which does pump up the PWM frequency. So that makes a little more sense of things.

Author: brettski74
Content: Ok - confirmed on v3.0 hardware at high frequency as well. I set the prescaler to 1, which bumped my PWM frequency to around 63kHz. Started a reflow cycle with that firmware mod with my finger on the input cap. Within a few seconds it got hot enough that I decided to take my finger off and cut the power.

Author: brettski74
Content: It's definitely a consequence of high ripple currents due to inadequate input capacitance for the load.

Author: brettski74
Content: The BOM says AFR. A means it's in a TQFP package, so you definitely want that first letter to be an A. F is the temperature range. F means -40 to +125 celsius. U means -40 to +80 celsius. You'll probably be fine with an AUR, but given this is a device designed to get hot, AFR is probably better. R means it's supplied on tape & reel. If the R is not there, it's supplied in a tube or tray. I don't think we would care about this.

Author: brettski74
Content: So A definitely, F probably and R don't care.

Author: brettski74
Content: 12V @ 2A is nowhere near enough power. For the V2.4 and V3.0 boards, you'll need at least 60W of power available, which means about 5A. More is better because of deficiencies in the design of those boards. Author: brettski74
Content: I'm assuming that you're having both boards and an SMT stencil manufactured for your layout. The paste layer is used to determine the location and size of the holes in the stencil, which is where the paste will go through onto your board. The solder mask layer specifies the areas of the PCB where there will be no solder mask. This is usually where you have pads that need to be exposed so solder can adhere to them. Normally, the pads on your paste layer would be equal to or smaller than the pads on your solder mask layer, so I assume they're asking whether you really want the holes in your stencil cut to the size in the paste layer, or should they really just be the same as the pads on the mask layer.

Content: Hey, is it possible to just create an custom Version (with bigger size) without changing Code or Hardware?

Author: brettski74
Content: For a version to be custom, you'd have to have changed something - either code or hardware and the bigger hotplate you've suggested would be a hardware change. Ignoring that, could you create a hotplate that is larger than some existing design and change nothing other than the size of the hotplate? That depends. A larger hotplate requires more power to achieve the same thermal performance. I don't know which design you're starting from - perhaps the AfterEarthLtd v3.0 design for example. I also don't know just how much bigger you want to go. Frankly, the hardware design of the AfterEarthLtd design isn't great and has some serious flaws when it comes to the power design, so I'd be wary of trying to pull more power through it. If you're talking about a better design with more of a buck-derived power stage, that might be more amenable to higher power, but you'd need to look at the capabilities of the inductor and MOSFET in use to make sure that you're not going to saturate the inductor or overheat the MOSFET. For higher power, you may also want to consider a higher voltage. 12V is ok for smaller hotplates, up to maybe 100mm x 100mm or so, but the larger you go, the more current you need to get the required power and this becomes more and more difficult to do. 20-24V is probably worth considering if you want to go larger than that. If you want to go much larger, then you may want to consider even higher voltages. Up to about 48V or so, it's safe and generally easier to deal with a little more voltage than it is to deal with the higher currents you might need.
